solutions.content:
# Code
It can be one line 😎
```
class Solution:

    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        a = 0.18280353296829546
        c = -0.09140176648414775 - 0.34054653082707936j
        d = 0.09140176648414775 + 0.34054653082707936j
        z1 = 0.5436890126920766
        z2 = -0.7718445063460382 + 1.1151425080399373j
        z3 = -0.7718445063460382 - 1.1151425080399373j
        res = a / math.pow(z1, n + 1) + c / pow(z2, n + 1) + d / pow(z3, n + 1)
        return round(res.real)
```
Micro performance tunning 🤓
`math.pow(z1,.)` - because `z1` is real $$\mathbb{R}$$, it's faster than just `pow`
`pow(z2,.)` - because `z2`,`z3` are complex $$\mathbb{C}$$

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(\log{n})$$ (because of `pow(num, n)`)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
When I was at university, we did a generating function for Fibonacci numbers. So I decided to make it for Tribonacci sequence.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
[Generating function wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generating_function)
Let 's use an Ordinary generating function (OGF)

$$G(z) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}z^nF_n$$

$$z^0F_0 = 0$$
$$z^1F_1 = z$$
$$z^2F_2 = z^2$$
$$z^nF_n = z^n(F_{n-1} + F_{n-2} + F_{n-3}), n >= 3$$


Sum both sides:
$$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}z^nF_n = z + z^2 + \sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^n(F_{n-1} + F_{n-2} + F_{n-3})$$
Replace some sums with $$G(z) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}z^nF_n$$
$$\sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^nF_{n-1} = z * \sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^{n-1}F_{n-1} = z * \sum_{n=2}^{\infty}z^{n}F_{n} = z*(G(z)-z^1F_1-z^0F_0) = z*(G(z)-z-0) = z*G(z)-z^2$$
$$\sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^nF_{n-2} = z^2 * \sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^{n-2}F_{n-2} = z^2 * \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}z^{n}F_{n} = z^2*G(z) = z^2*(G(z) - z^0F_0) = z^2*(G(z) - 0) = z^2*G(z)$$
$$\sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^nF_{n-3} = z^3 * \sum_{n=3}^{\infty}z^{n-3}F_{n-3} = z^3 * \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}z^{n}F_{n} = z^3*G(z)$$
$$G(z) = z + z ^ 2 + z*G(z) - z^2 + z^2*G(z) + z^3*G(z)$$
$$G(z) = z + z*G(z) + z^2*G(z) + z^3*G(z)$$
$$G(z) - z*(G(z)-z) - z^2*G(z) - z^3*G(z) = z$$
$$G(z)(1-z-z^2-z^3)=z$$
$$G(z) = \frac{z}{1-z-z^2-z^3}$$

Now it needs to transform in such view from which it's possible to apply formula of the sum of an infinitely decreasing geometric progression:
$$\frac{1}{1-kz}=1+kz+(kz)^2+...=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}k^nz^n$$.

For this it needs to solve this equation $$1 - z - z^2 - z^3$$.
Let's solve it, you need to type in Google `solve cubic equation online` 👁👄👁

There are 3 solutions to this equation:
* One solution is in real numbers $$\mathbb{R}$$: $$z_1=0.5436890126920766$$;
* Two solutions are in complex numbers $$\mathbb{C}$$:
    * $$z_2=-0.7718445063460382+i1.1151425080399373$$,
    * $$z_3=-0.7718445063460382-i1.1151425080399373$$.

First decompose:
$$\frac{z}{1-z-z^2-z^3}=\frac{a}{z-z_1}+\frac{b}{(z-z_2)(z-z_3)}$$
Multiply both sides on $$1-z-z^2-z^3$$
$$z=a(z-z_2)(z-z_3)+b(z-z_1)$$
Put $$z_1$$ to the equation above than $$a=\frac{z_1}{(z_1-z_2)(z_1-z_3)}$$
$$a=0.18280353296829546$$
Put $$z_2$$ to the equation and get $$b=\frac{z_2}{z_2-z_1}$$
$$b=0.7595158249816182-i0.2038519902328264$$

Second decompose:
$$\frac{b}{(z-z_2)(z-z_3)}=\frac{c}{z-z_2}+\frac{d}{z-z_3}$$
$$b=c(z-z_3)+d(z-z_2)$$
Put $$z_2$$ to the equation above than $$c=\frac{b}{z_2-z_3}$$
$$c=-0.09140176648414775-i0.34054653082707936$$
Put $$z_3$$ to the equation and get $$d=\frac{b}{z_3-z_2}$$
$$d=0.09140176648414775+i0.34054653082707936$$

Let's write decomposed fraction:
$$\frac{z}{1-z-z^2-z^3}=\frac{a}{z-z_1}+\frac{c}{z-z_2}+\frac{d}{z-z_3}$$

Each small fraction transform to $$\frac{1}{1-kz}=1+kz+(kz)^2+...=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}k^nz^n$$
$$\frac{a}{z-z_1}=-\frac{a}{z_1}\frac{1}{1-\frac{z}{z_1}}=-\frac{a}{z_1}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{1}{z_1})^n*z^n$$
$$\frac{c}{z-z_2}=-\frac{c}{z_2}\frac{1}{1-\frac{z}{z_2}}=-\frac{c}{z_2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{1}{z_2})^n*z^n$$
$$\frac{d}{z-z_3}=-\frac{d}{z_3}\frac{1}{1-\frac{z}{z_3}}=-\frac{d}{z_3}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{1}{z_3})^n*z^n$$

I don't know where I made a mistake but there is no need in minus (-) before them :)
Please point on my mistake if you find it

$$G(z)=\frac{a}{z_1}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{1}{z_1})^n*z^n + \frac{c}{z_2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{1}{z_2})^n*z^n + \frac{d}{z_3}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{1}{z_3})^n*z^n=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{a}{z_1^{n+1}}+\frac{c}{z_2^{n+1}}+\frac{d}{z_3^{n+1}})z^n$$
Remind you that $$G(z) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}z^nF_n$$ than $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{a}{z_1^{n+1}}+\frac{c}{z_2^{n+1}}+\frac{d}{z_3^{n+1}})z^n=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}F_nz^n$$
$$F_n=\frac{a}{z_1^{n+1}}+\frac{c}{z_2^{n+1}}+\frac{d}{z_3^{n+1}}$$

```
class Solution:

    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        a = 0.18280353296829546
        c = -0.09140176648414775 - 0.34054653082707936j
        d = 0.09140176648414775 + 0.34054653082707936j
        z1 = 0.5436890126920766
        z2 = -0.7718445063460382 + 1.1151425080399373j
        z3 = -0.7718445063460382 - 1.1151425080399373j
        res = a / math.pow(z1, n + 1) + c / pow(z2, n + 1) + d / pow(z3, n + 1)
        return round(res.real)
```

Runtime: 32 ms, **faster than 91.32%** of Python3 online submissions for N-th Tribonacci Number.
Memory Usage: 13.7 MB, **less than 97.00%** of Python3 online submissions for N-th Tribonacci Number.


```
class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        t0, t1, t2 = 0, 1, 1
        if n == 0 or n == 1:
            return n
        if n == 2:
            return 1
        
        for i in range(2, n):
            t = t0 + t1 + t2
            t2, t1, t0 = t, t2, t1
        
        return t
```

Python O(n) by 1D DP.

[中文詳解解題影片 Tutorial video in Chinese](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fNFcRT7Fswc)

[My tutorial of DP problem solving framework to Tribonacci number [ English ]](https://medium.com/@cutesciuridae/dive-into-dp-take-tribonacci-number-for-example-34fe657d35cb)

[My tutorial of DP problem solving framework to Tribonacci number [ Chinese ]](https://medium.com/@cutesciuridae/dynamic-programming-%E6%B7%B1%E5%85%A5%E6%B7%BA%E5%87%BA-%E4%BB%A5n-th-tribonacci-number-%E7%82%BA%E4%BE%8B-2d120c935a85?source=your_stories_page-------------------------------------)

---

```python []

# Top-down DP without space optimization
# O(n) time
# O(n) space

class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        
        # DP table with base case
        # key: index i
        # value: corresponding Trib(i)
        memo = {
            0: 0,
            1: 1,
            2: 1
        }

        def dp( i ):

            if i in memo:
                return memo[i]

            # General caess
            memo[i] = dp(i-3) + dp(i-2) + dp(i-1)
            return memo[i]
        #-------------------------
        return dp(n)
```
```python []

# Bottom-up DP without space optimization
# O(n) time
# O(n) space

class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:

        # DP table with base case
        # key: index i
        # value: corresponding Trib(i)
        memo = {
            0: 0,
            1: 1,
            2: 1
        }

        # General caess
        for i in range(3, n+1):
            memo[i] = memo[i-1] + memo[i-2] + memo[i-3]

        return memo[n]     
```
```python []

# Bottom-up DP with space optimization
# O(n) time
# O(1) space

class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        
        # DP table with base case
        # key: index i
        # value: corresponding Trib(i)
        memo = {
            0: 0,
            1: 1,
            2: 1
        }

        # General cases
        # with space optimization
        for i in range(3, n+1):
            memo[i%3] = memo[(i-1)%3] + memo[(i-2)%3] + memo[(i-3)%3]

        return memo[n%3]  
```

```python []
        return dp(n)
```
```python []

# Bottom-up DP without space optimization
# O(n) time
# O(n) space

class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:

        # DP table with base case
        # key: index i
        # value: corresponding Trib(i)
        memo = {
            0: 0,
            1: 1,
            2: 1
        }

        # General caess
        for i in range(3, n+1):
            memo[i] = memo[i-1] + memo[i-2] + memo[i-3]

        return memo[n]     
```
```python []

# Bottom-up DP with space optimization
# O(n) time
# O(1) space

class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        
        # DP table with base case
        # key: index i
        # value: corresponding Trib(i)
        memo = {
            0: 0,
            1: 1,
            2: 1
        }

        # General cases
        # with space optimization
        for i in range(3, n+1):
            memo[i%3] = memo[(i-1)%3] + memo[(i-2)%3] + memo[(i-3)%3]

        return memo[n%3]  
```

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
a array of size 3 is there it has values of `fib(0),fib(1),fib(2)`
furthur usig thier sum we append it to end of list and pop the first element
at end answer will be stored in last `a[2]` returning it does the job

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
**______O(N)**

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        if n==0:return 0
        d=[0]*(3)
        d[0]=0
        d[1]=d[2]=1
        for i in range(3,n+1):
            d.append(sum(d))
            d.pop(0)
        return d[2]
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
There would be three special cases, n= 0, n=1 and n=2 where T1 = 0, T2 = 1, T3 = 1 can be hardcoded.
For subsequent Terms, add the last three elements.
e.g. for T4 = T1 + T2 + T3 (0+1+1) = 2
for T5 = T4 + T3 + T2 (1+1+2) = 4
and so on.
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
let 

n1 => last element,
n2 => 2nd last element,
n3 => 3rd last element

Run a loop starting from 3 upto n.
keep assigning the next val to the last three vals.

then 
n3,n2,n1 = n2, n1, n1+n2+n3

after the loop is completed, n3 is the answer.

<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
- O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
Constant
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
func tribonacci(n int) int {
    if n <=1 {
        return n
    }
    if n == 2{
        return 1
    }

    var t1, t2, t3 int = 0,1,1

    for i:=3; i<n+1; i++{
        t1,t2,t3 = t2,t3,t1+t2+t3
    }
    return t3
}
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
This problem is similar to the Fibonacci sequence, it just adds one more base case. In general, we use a list or array to record subproblems we've computed before. However, in this problem, we can just utilize three variables `a, b, c` to solve it.

# Approach
We start our loop from `3` to `n` (inclusive), In the end, return `c` if `n` is not equal to `0`, else return `0`.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$ 

- Space complexity:
 $$O(1)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def tribonacci(self, n: int) -> int:
        a, b, c = 0, 1, 1
        for _ in range(3, n + 1):
            c, b, a = a + b + c, c, b
        return c if n != 0 else 0
```

# Approach
Used simple approach as in Fibonacci series.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
Add your time complexity here is O(n)

- Space complexity:
Add your space complexity here is O(1)
# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def tribonacci(self, n):
        """
        :type n: int
        :rtype: int
        """
        n1=0
        n2=1
        n3=1
        if n==0:
            return n1
        for i in range(n-2):
            n1,n2,n3=n2,n3,(n1+n2+n3)
        return n3
```

Don't want to bother understanding what this line means?:
T0 = 0, T1 = 1, T2 = 1, and Tn+3 = Tn + Tn+1 + Tn+2 for n >= 0.

Basically, all a Tribonacci number is, is the sum of the preceding three numbers
Here is a sample sequence:
0 1 1 2 4 7 13

0 + 1 + 1 = 2
1 + 1 + 2 = 4
1 + 2 + 4 = 7
2 + 4 + 7 = 13

Hope that clarifies things!
Should Leonardo Fibonacci be called Leonardo Dibonacci or Bibonacci?
Leonardo Couplebonacci

Can we do this with matrix exponentiation for O(log(n)) time, as it is possible for [fibonacci numbers](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/867394/how-to-compute-the-nth-number-of-a-general-fibonacci-sequence-with-matrix-multip)?

Maybe the following 3 x 3 matrix is the building block we need?
```
1 1 1
1 0 0
0 1 0
```

Yes, every linear recursion can be written in the matrix form(since matrices describe linear transformations) and then the same trick with fast matrix exponentiation can be applied. However, one needs to be a bit more careful, since multiplying matrices also takes significant time. Ideally you will need to write it in the Jordan normal form before applying the fast multiplication trick.

As for your transformation: it sends (a, b, c) to (a+b+c, a, b) so indeed if you start with the vector (f_n, f_{n-1}, f_{n-2}) you will get (f_{n+1}, f_n, f_{n-1}).
same bro\n

If you're getting a TLE error when using the recursive formula return tribonacci(n-1)+tribonacci(n-2)+tribonacci(n-3);, it's likely due to the fact that this implementation uses a lot of recursive function calls.

Each time the tribonacci function is called recursively, it creates a new stack frame and takes up memory. If the number n is large, the number of recursive function calls can become very large, leading to a large amount of memory being used and slowing down the program.

To avoid this issue, you could use an iterative approach like the one I used in my solution URL: https://leetcode.com/problems/n-th-tribonacci-number/solutions/3335471/easiest-solution-beats-100-dynamic-programming-time-and-space-complexity/ 
The iterative approach only requires a fixed amount of memory for the array T and runs in linear time.
Did a recursive like in a regular fibonacci but got TLE at n = 30. What should I do?
You should use dp to store values
don\'t repeatedly add the same 3 numbers again and again hundreds of thousands of times if you have already added them together once
use dp
you only need 4 variables and a for loop, done

Make an array of size n+1 and store the values you get in recursion in that array... like arr[4]=4th tribonacci number. Also check if you have value already in array before calling function each time. This will save time and avoid repeated work for you. It\'s called Memoization ...
Use dynamic programming, either recursively with memoization or iteratively.

You can write a "memoized" solution which caches previous computations effectively "pruning" the recursion tree. Checkout this link [Fibonacci and Memoization](https://medium.com/@porzingod/fibonacci-and-memoization-e99f765b97f6) for an explanation.

Can we do this with matrix exponentiation for O(log(n)) time, as it is possible for [fibonacci numbers](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/867394/how-to-compute-the-nth-number-of-a-general-fibonacci-sequence-with-matrix-multip)?

Maybe the following 3 x 3 matrix is the building block we need?
```
1 1 1
1 0 0
0 1 0
```

Yes, every linear recursion can be written in the matrix form(since matrices describe linear transformations) and then the same trick with fast matrix exponentiation can be applied. However, one needs to be a bit more careful, since multiplying matrices also takes significant time. Ideally you will need to write it in the Jordan normal form before applying the fast multiplication trick.

As for your transformation: it sends (a, b, c) to (a+b+c, a, b) so indeed if you start with the vector (f_n, f_{n-1}, f_{n-2}) you will get (f_{n+1}, f_n, f_{n-1}).
same bro\n

If you're getting a TLE error when using the recursive formula return tribonacci(n-1)+tribonacci(n-2)+tribonacci(n-3);, it's likely due to the fact that this implementation uses a lot of recursive function calls.

Each time the tribonacci function is called recursively, it creates a new stack frame and takes up memory. If the number n is large, the number of recursive function calls can become very large, leading to a large amount of memory being used and slowing down the program.

To avoid this issue, you could use an iterative approach like the one I used in my solution URL: https://leetcode.com/problems/n-th-tribonacci-number/solutions/3335471/easiest-solution-beats-100-dynamic-programming-time-and-space-complexity/ 
The iterative approach only requires a fixed amount of memory for the array T and runs in linear time.
Did a recursive like in a regular fibonacci but got TLE at n = 30. What should I do?
You should use dp to store values
don\'t repeatedly add the same 3 numbers again and again hundreds of thousands of times if you have already added them together once
use dp
you only need 4 variables and a for loop, done

Make an array of size n+1 and store the values you get in recursion in that array... like arr[4]=4th tribonacci number. Also check if you have value already in array before calling function each time. This will save time and avoid repeated work for you. It\'s called Memoization ...
Use dynamic programming, either recursively with memoization or iteratively.

You can write a "memoized" solution which caches previous computations effectively "pruning" the recursion tree. Checkout this link [Fibonacci and Memoization](https://medium.com/@porzingod/fibonacci-and-memoization-e99f765b97f6) for an explanation.
Finally EASY problem \uD83E\uDD72
Much needed respite!

Don't want to bother understanding what this line means?:
T0 = 0, T1 = 1, T2 = 1, and Tn+3 = Tn + Tn+1 + Tn+2 for n >= 0.

Basically, all a Tribonacci number is, is the sum of the preceding three numbers
Here is a sample sequence:
0 1 1 2 4 7 13

0 + 1 + 1 = 2
1 + 1 + 2 = 4
1 + 2 + 4 = 7
2 + 4 + 7 = 13

Hope that clarifies things!

Don't want to bother understanding what this line means?:
T0 = 0, T1 = 1, T2 = 1, and Tn+3 = Tn + Tn+1 + Tn+2 for n >= 0.

Basically, all a Tribonacci number is, is the sum of the preceding three numbers
Here is a sample sequence:
0 1 1 2 4 7 13

0 + 1 + 1 = 2
1 + 1 + 2 = 4
1 + 2 + 4 = 7
2 + 4 + 7 = 13

Hope that clarifies things!
Should Leonardo Fibonacci be called Leonardo Dibonacci or Bibonacci?
Leonardo Couplebonacci

Can we do this with matrix exponentiation for O(log(n)) time, as it is possible for [fibonacci numbers](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/867394/how-to-compute-the-nth-number-of-a-general-fibonacci-sequence-with-matrix-multip)?

Maybe the following 3 x 3 matrix is the building block we need?
```
1 1 1
1 0 0
0 1 0
```

Yes, every linear recursion can be written in the matrix form(since matrices describe linear transformations) and then the same trick with fast matrix exponentiation can be applied. However, one needs to be a bit more careful, since multiplying matrices also takes significant time. Ideally you will need to write it in the Jordan normal form before applying the fast multiplication trick.

As for your transformation: it sends (a, b, c) to (a+b+c, a, b) so indeed if you start with the vector (f_n, f_{n-1}, f_{n-2}) you will get (f_{n+1}, f_n, f_{n-1}).
same bro\n

If you're getting a TLE error when using the recursive formula return tribonacci(n-1)+tribonacci(n-2)+tribonacci(n-3);, it's likely due to the fact that this implementation uses a lot of recursive function calls.

Each time the tribonacci function is called recursively, it creates a new stack frame and takes up memory. If the number n is large, the number of recursive function calls can become very large, leading to a large amount of memory being used and slowing down the program.

To avoid this issue, you could use an iterative approach like the one I used in my solution URL: https://leetcode.com/problems/n-th-tribonacci-number/solutions/3335471/easiest-solution-beats-100-dynamic-programming-time-and-space-complexity/ 
The iterative approach only requires a fixed amount of memory for the array T and runs in linear time.
Did a recursive like in a regular fibonacci but got TLE at n = 30. What should I do?
You should use dp to store values
don\'t repeatedly add the same 3 numbers again and again hundreds of thousands of times if you have already added them together once
use dp
you only need 4 variables and a for loop, done

Make an array of size n+1 and store the values you get in recursion in that array... like arr[4]=4th tribonacci number. Also check if you have value already in array before calling function each time. This will save time and avoid repeated work for you. It\'s called Memoization ...
Use dynamic programming, either recursively with memoization or iteratively.

You can write a "memoized" solution which caches previous computations effectively "pruning" the recursion tree. Checkout this link [Fibonacci and Memoization](https://medium.com/@porzingod/fibonacci-and-memoization-e99f765b97f6) for an explanation.
Finally EASY problem \uD83E\uDD72
Much needed respite!

Can we do this with matrix exponentiation for O(log(n)) time, as it is possible for [fibonacci numbers](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/867394/how-to-compute-the-nth-number-of-a-general-fibonacci-sequence-with-matrix-multip)?

Maybe the following 3 x 3 matrix is the building block we need?
```
1 1 1
1 0 0
0 1 0
```

Yes, every linear recursion can be written in the matrix form(since matrices describe linear transformations) and then the same trick with fast matrix exponentiation can be applied. However, one needs to be a bit more careful, since multiplying matrices also takes significant time. Ideally you will need to write it in the Jordan normal form before applying the fast multiplication trick.

As for your transformation: it sends (a, b, c) to (a+b+c, a, b) so indeed if you start with the vector (f_n, f_{n-1}, f_{n-2}) you will get (f_{n+1}, f_n, f_{n-1}).
same bro\n

If you're getting a TLE error when using the recursive formula return tribonacci(n-1)+tribonacci(n-2)+tribonacci(n-3);, it's likely due to the fact that this implementation uses a lot of recursive function calls.

Each time the tribonacci function is called recursively, it creates a new stack frame and takes up memory. If the number n is large, the number of recursive function calls can become very large, leading to a large amount of memory being used and slowing down the program.

To avoid this issue, you could use an iterative approach like the one I used in my solution URL: https://leetcode.com/problems/n-th-tribonacci-number/solutions/3335471/easiest-solution-beats-100-dynamic-programming-time-and-space-complexity/ 
The iterative approach only requires a fixed amount of memory for the array T and runs in linear time.

Great... but what exactly do you want to discuss here in discussion section where people rescue for tips?

This problem would by more interesting for n bigger than 37, when it would be necessary to reduce time complexity to logarithmic.\nFor example the task could be to calculate T_n mod 1000 000 000 (to fit in 32-bit)
[@shrutika051220](/shrutika051220) implement memoization else overlapping subproblems will be calculated again and again. Store it in a dp table.

If you're getting a TLE error when using the recursive formula return tribonacci(n-1)+tribonacci(n-2)+tribonacci(n-3);, it's likely due to the fact that this implementation uses a lot of recursive function calls.

Each time the tribonacci function is called recursively, it creates a new stack frame and takes up memory. If the number n is large, the number of recursive function calls can become very large, leading to a large amount of memory being used and slowing down the program.

To avoid this issue, you could use an iterative approach like the one I used in my solution URL: https://leetcode.com/problems/n-th-tribonacci-number/solutions/3335471/easiest-solution-beats-100-dynamic-programming-time-and-space-complexity/
The iterative approach only requires a fixed amount of memory for the array T and runs in linear time.
for n=30 you're adding 3 numbers 18947744 times, while you only need to add 3 numbers 28 times to get from t_0, t_1 and t_2 to t_30
[@shrutika051220](/shrutika051220) because without memoization or other techniques to not recalculate a state multiple times, your actual complexity is exponential and not linear.

Great... but what exactly do you want to discuss here in discussion section where people rescue for tips?

This problem would by more interesting for n bigger than 37, when it would be necessary to reduce time complexity to logarithmic.\nFor example the task could be to calculate T_n mod 1000 000 000 (to fit in 32-bit)
[@shrutika051220](/shrutika051220) implement memoization else overlapping subproblems will be calculated again and again. Store it in a dp table.

If you're getting a TLE error when using the recursive formula return tribonacci(n-1)+tribonacci(n-2)+tribonacci(n-3);, it's likely due to the fact that this implementation uses a lot of recursive function calls.

Each time the tribonacci function is called recursively, it creates a new stack frame and takes up memory. If the number n is large, the number of recursive function calls can become very large, leading to a large amount of memory being used and slowing down the program.

To avoid this issue, you could use an iterative approach like the one I used in my solution URL: https://leetcode.com/problems/n-th-tribonacci-number/solutions/3335471/easiest-solution-beats-100-dynamic-programming-time-and-space-complexity/
The iterative approach only requires a fixed amount of memory for the array T and runs in linear time.
for n=30 you're adding 3 numbers 18947744 times, while you only need to add 3 numbers 28 times to get from t_0, t_1 and t_2 to t_30
[@shrutika051220](/shrutika051220) because without memoization or other techniques to not recalculate a state multiple times, your actual complexity is exponential and not linear.

What a fucking awful way of explaining the problem, it says T(n+3) = T(n) + T(n+1) + T(n+2) which is NOT correct, since you are given n, the correct way of explaining it would be for n==0, T(n) == 0; for 0<n<3, T(n) == 1; for n>=3, T(n) = T(n-1) + T(n-2) + T(n-3), since you are given n, basing the explanation on T(n+3) is both stupid and unnecessary.

This is one of the LeetCode 75 questions (the only reason I am doing it).
If this is the first time you have ever heard of Dynamic Programming then this is a good place to start. There are many YouTubes that explain why using recursion to calculate Fibonacci numbers is a bad idea and how to use DP to speed up the calculation. Once you understand the concept, you can easily adapt the solution for Fibonacci numbers to this one.

title: Maximum Number of Visible Points
question_content:
You are given an array points, an integer angle, and your location, where location = [posx, posy] and points[i] = [xi, yi] both denote integral coordinates on the X-Y plane.

Initially, you are facing directly east from your position. You cannot move from your position, but you can rotate. In other words, posx and posy cannot be changed. Your field of view in degrees is represented by angle, determining how wide you can see from any given view direction. Let d be the amount in degrees that you rotate counterclockwise. Then, your field of view is the inclusive range of angles [d - angle/2, d + angle/2].

You can see some set of points if, for each point, the angle formed by the point, your position, and the immediate east direction from your position is in your field of view.

There can be multiple points at one coordinate. There may be points at your location, and you can always see these points regardless of your rotation. Points do not obstruct your vision to other points.

Return the maximum number of points you can see.

 

Example 1:

Input: points = [[2,1],[2,2],[3,3]], angle = 90, location = [1,1]
Output: 3
Explanation: The shaded region represents your field of view. All points can be made visible in your field of view, including [3,3] even though [2,2] is in front and in the same line of sight.

Example 2:

Input: points = [[2,1],[2,2],[3,4],[1,1]], angle = 90, location = [1,1]
Output: 4
Explanation: All points can be made visible in your field of view, including the one at your location.

Example 3:

Input: points = [[1,0],[2,1]], angle = 13, location = [1,1]
Output: 1
Explanation: You can only see one of the two points, as shown above.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= points.length <= 105
  • points[i].length == 2
  • location.length == 2
  • 0 <= angle < 360
  • 0 <= posx, posy, xi, yi <= 100

solutions.title: python-clean-sliding-window-solution-with-explanation
solutions.content:
**Idea**

Here are the steps:

1) convert all coordinates to radians 
2) sort the array
3) use sliding window to find the longest window that satisfies `arr[r] - arr[l] <= angle`.

Note that we need to go around the circle, so we duplicate the array and offset the second half by 2*pi.

</br>


**Complexity**

Time complexity: `O(NlogN)`
Space complexity: `O(N)`

</br>

**Python**
```Python
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        
        arr, extra = [], 0
        xx, yy = location
        
        for x, y in points:
            if x == xx and y == yy:
                extra += 1
                continue
            arr.append(math.atan2(y - yy, x - xx))
        
        arr.sort()
        arr = arr + [x + 2.0 * math.pi for x in arr]
        angle = math.pi * angle / 180
        
        l = ans = 0
        for r in range(len(arr)):
            while arr[r] - arr[l] > angle:
                l += 1
            ans = max(ans, r - l + 1)
            
        return ans + extra
```

solutions.content: ```html5 Time Complexity: O(n·log(n)) Space Complexity: O(n) ``` **Notes:** 1. ```math.atan2(y,x)``` is used instead of ```math.atan``` because it accounts for the sign of x and y. ```html5 math.atan2(-1, -1) * (180 / π) = -135° math.atan2(1, 1) * (180 / π) = 45° math.atan(1/1) * (180 / π) = 45° math.atan(-1/-1) * (180 / π) = 45° ``` 2. Python: Step 2 is written for readability. It is more efficient to replace step 2 with the following code: ```python angles = sorted((angle_from_me(p) for p in points)) if not angles: return points_on_me max_angle = angles[-1] for a in angles: if a + 360 > max_angle + angle: break angles.append(a + 360) ``` 3. C++: `double` is used for angles for higher precision. If you are using C++ and obtaining a result that contains one or two points more than the expected result for just a few of the test cases, try increasing the precision by using `double`.
solutions.code: ```html5 Time Complexity: O(n·log(n)) Space Complexity: O(n) ``` ```math.atan2(y,x)``` ```math.atan``` ```html5 math.atan2(-1, -1) * (180 / π) = -135° math.atan2(1, 1) * (180 / π) = 45° math.atan(1/1) * (180 / π) = 45° math.atan(-1/-1) * (180 / π) = 45° ``` ```python angles = sorted((angle_from_me(p) for p in points)) if not angles: return points_on_me max_angle = angles[-1] for a in angles: if a + 360 > max_angle + angle: break angles.append(a + 360) ```

solutions.title: c-atan2-and-sliding-window
c-clean-and-commented-code-sliding-window-solution
python-visual-explanation-sliding-window-complexity-analysis
solutions.content:
Finding Angle is basic trigonometry => **SOHCAHTOA**, remember? lol
Chose to use **TOA** because no extra step to find **Opp**(locY - pY) and **Adj** (locX - pX)

tan(angle) = Opposite / Adjacent => **inverse of tan(opposite / adjacent) = angle**
inverse of tan in python is atan() and atan2()

atan2() return between -pi and pi wheres atan only returns between -pi/2 and pi/2
In this case, we not only care about angles, but positions in 360 angles, so **atan2()** can be useful here.
*FYI Syntax-wise, atan() takes one argument, and atan2() takes two argument*

**STEPS**
1. find all the angles of points to the location
2. make sure to count the point where positioned exactly same as location (add to your result later as prompt stated)
3. For all the founded angles, **add 360 and merge them into array of angles we found previously** => Say your lowest angle = -174 then adding 360 will be 186 and this will be added to your array as new point.
	- This is important because, we are going to use sliding window to count maximum sub-array with the boundary(angle) given, however, if we do this with just initially founded angles, we are not considering the case when the person is looking at -pi, in other words, when you are at the end of array, you should still consider the points at the start of the array. **(Please look at GIF)**
4. Sliding window to find maximum length sub-array that falls between angle at pointer 'l' and 'l + angle'

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/97a1af1f-5346-4188-a0a7-1e3b2a5e4d45_1644520012.1160696.gif)


**Complexity**
 **Time - O(Plog(P))** for sorting of an array length of (2P) where P represent number of points
 **Space - O(P)** for the array to store angles
 
```
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        locX, locY = location[0], location[1]
        pAngles = []
        locCount = 0
        
        # find angle from location O(P)
        for point in points:
            xp, yp = point[0], point[1]
            if (yp - locY) == 0 and (xp - locX) == 0:
                locCount += 1
                continue
            else:
                pAngle = math.degrees(math.atan2((xp - locX), (yp - locY)))
            pAngles.append(pAngle)
        
        # Add same angles in quadrant but from 180 to 540
        # explain in the above graphics
        pAngles += [a + 360 for a in pAngles] # O(P)
        # sort so we can slide window # O(P log(P))
        pAngles.sort()
        
        # Sliding Window to find maximum subarray within the angle given # O(P)
        maxCount = 0
        l, r = 0, 0
        while r < len(pAngles):
            while r < len(pAngles) and pAngles[r] <= pAngles[l] + angle:
                r += 1
            maxCount = max(maxCount, r - l)
            l += 1
        
        return maxCount + locCount
 ```

```
        # find angle from location O(P)

            xp, yp = point[0], point[1]
            if (yp - locY) == 0 and (xp - locX) == 0:
                locCount += 1
                continue
            else:
                pAngle = math.degrees(math.atan2((xp - locX), (yp - locY)))
            pAngles.append(pAngle)
        
        # Add same angles in quadrant but from 180 to 540
        # explain in the above graphics
        pAngles += [a + 360 for a in pAngles] # O(P)
        # sort so we can slide window # O(P log(P))
        pAngles.sort()
        
        # Sliding Window to find maximum subarray within the angle given # O(P)

            l += 1
        
        return maxCount + locCount
 ```

solutions.title: python-100-100-clean-commented-and-explained
solutions.content:
The basic algorithm I used was to compute the polar angles (while counting/removing any points which coincided with your 'location'), then sort the angles, and then count the number of points in each relevant sector using 2 pointers (slow/fast) remembering that the circle wraps around. Below is an animation I made illustrating the 2-pointer algorithm used in this problem. The slow pointer is represented by the green line, its point is included in the current count. The fast pointer is represented by the red line, its point is NOT included in the current count.

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/14120012-543e-41a3-aa51-e791f1086792_1625878700.2866209.gif)

Instead of using this version of the 2-pointer solution, it's also possible to solve the puzzle by binary searching for the next point, alternately updating the fast and slow pointers. I think this has been slightly faster in practice, but I haven't implemented it yet.

Next, I need to talk about my memory usage. While I did do some things to legitamately keep my memory usage lower (like using a cyclic array rather than appending a second copy of the array to itself), the main reason my memory usage is so low is because I kinda cheated. Instead of just storing the angles in a new array, I first removed them from the given array 'points'. This means that while my solution uses O(n) auxillary memory, in terms of how LeetCode measures memory usage its effectively an O(1) solution (I personally think it's bs that I can do this, but hate the game not the player, right?).

Time Complexity : O(nlogn)
Memory Complexity : O(n)
Best Performance : 2044 ms/37.5 MB : 100%/100%
'''

    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        #Compute the Angles of Each Point Relative to Yourself : O(n)
        angles = []
        Y, X = location.pop(), location.pop() #I'm just being extra about the memory thing here...
        m = 0
        for i in range(len(points)):
            #Get the Next Point
            x, y = points.pop()
            
            #Check if the Point is Not at Your Location
            if x != X or y != Y:
                #Compute the Angle of the Point in Radians
                angles.append(atan2(y - Y, x - X))
            else:
                #Record that the Point Exists
                m += 1
        
        #Sort the Remaining Angles : O(nlogn)
        angles.sort()
        
        #Convert the Angle to Radians
        angle *= pi/180
        
        #2-Pointer Solution : O(n)
        j = 1
        n = 0
        N = len(angles)
        for J, i in enumerate(range(N), start = N):
            #Increment j as Much as Possible to Find the Points in the Current Sector
            while j < J and (angles[j%N] - angles[i])%tau <= angle:
                j += 1
            
            #Check the Case
            if j == J:
                #The Result is Optimal
                return m + N
            else:
                #Save the Best Result so Far
                n = max(n, j - i)
        
        #Return the Maximum Number of Points
        return m + n
'''
Note that 'atan2', 'pi', and 'tau' are all included in python's math library, which is imported by default in LeetCode. Also, because 'atan2' outputs an angle in radians, I chose to work in radians throughout instead of in degrees like the problem was presented.

Edit: A previous version of my code wrote the angles to the 'points' array and saved which points to delete in a separate array. This algorithm was slightly slower, and used a few more MB of memory (its best performance was 2100 ms/40.4 MB). If you'd like to see the code for this version of the algorithm, it's the demo code for the 40.4-41.4 MB submissions.

Best Performance : 2044 ms/37.5 MB : 100%/100%
'''

    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        #Compute the Angles of Each Point Relative to Yourself : O(n)
        angles = []
        Y, X = location.pop(), location.pop() #I'm just being extra about the memory thing here...
        m = 0
        for i in range(len(points)):
            #Get the Next Point
            x, y = points.pop()
            
            #Check if the Point is Not at Your Location
            if x != X or y != Y:
                #Compute the Angle of the Point in Radians
                angles.append(atan2(y - Y, x - X))
            else:
                #Record that the Point Exists
                m += 1
        
        #Sort the Remaining Angles : O(nlogn)
        angles.sort()
        
        #Convert the Angle to Radians
        angle *= pi/180
        
        #2-Pointer Solution : O(n)
        j = 1
        n = 0
        N = len(angles)
        for J, i in enumerate(range(N), start = N):
            #Increment j as Much as Possible to Find the Points in the Current Sector
            while j < J and (angles[j%N] - angles[i])%tau <= angle:
                j += 1
            
            #Check the Case
            if j == J:
                #The Result is Optimal
                return m + N
            else:
                #Save the Best Result so Far
                n = max(n, j - i)
        
        #Return the Maximum Number of Points
        return m + n
'''
Note that 'atan2', 'pi', and 'tau' are all included in python's math library, which is imported by default in LeetCode. Also, because 'atan2' outputs an angle in radians, I chose to work in radians throughout instead of in degrees like the problem was presented.

Edit: A previous version of my code wrote the angles to the 'points' array and saved which points to delete in a separate array. This algorithm was slightly slower, and used a few more MB of memory (its best performance was 2100 ms/40.4 MB). If you'd like to see the code for this version of the algorithm, it's the demo code for the 40.4-41.4 MB submissions.

solutions.content:
This solution is best practise of other similar solutions. It took me a while to understand why we need:
**1. Calculate degrees between stand location and each point.**
Imagine you stand on the location, and rotate yourself. You can always see all points after you rotated 360 degrees, so, you can transfer the relation between your location (two numbers) and each point (another two numbers) to angle(a single number), which would decrease the complecity a lot!
As you start from East, postive X axis will be 0 degree. 
The math equation would be: **math.degrees(math.atan2(deltaY, deltaX))**
***Note: If a point is the same as location, you will always see it regardless, so we won't consider them in step 2.*** 

**2. Use sliding window to find max number of points.** 
After we got all the angles and sort them, the problem then became to: When I saw angle X, how many previous angles are still in my feild of view? 
Two pointers sliding window is the best way to solve this kind of issue.  
Pointer `j` go through all the angles, while pointer `i` keep the smallest angle which is still visible within feild of view.
***Note: There is an issue that degree 0 is actually the same as 360, we are checking a sliding window in a circle, but the array is a straight line. The best way to solve this sort of cycle issue is to attach the same array in the end, with every angle plus 360 degrees.***      

Lastly, don't forget to include the points which are the same as the location (len(points) - len(res))

```
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, l: List[int]) -> int:        
        # start from east, build angles for each point, exclude point same as stand point
        res = sorted([math.degrees(math.atan2((p[1] - l[1]), (p[0] - l[0]))) for p in points if p != l])        
        
        # build slide window
        angles = res + [x + 360 for x in res]         
        i = 0            
        best = 0            
        for j, ang in enumerate(angles):                
            while ang - angles[i] > angle:                    
                i += 1                    
            best = max(best, j - i + 1)              
        
        return best + (len(points) - len(res))      
```

solutions.title: sliding-window-algorithm-java
angle-sliding-window-intuition-behind-polar-coordinates
solutions.content:
# Intuition
The maximum number of points within the given Field Of View (FOV) is the maximum of the number of points contained in the interval window $$[\theta, \theta+ FOV]$$ of size $$FOV$$, which starts at angle $$x$$ and considers the angle range up to $$x+FOV$$ inclusive.
To attain this, every point has to be represented by its angle with respect to the x-axis relative to the observer (horizontal axis).
Since the problem assumes that we are able to observe:
- all points in the interval FOV up to infinity
- all points which are behind others in the same line of sight

Then we do not care about the distance of any point from the observer location. Only the angle at which is located is relevant so solve the problem   
# Real world application
This problem provides a simplified setting in which points captured by a LiDAR sensor have to be filtered so as to consider only the ones falling within the field of view of a given RGB camera sensor.
E.g. to obtian occupancy maps of the environment for an autonomous driving application.

## Simplified algorithm
Note: the below simplified algorithm gives only a simple intuition about a sliding window solution which is then refined in the actual approach. 
This one would give "off by 1" or "off by 2 errors" due to the rounding of angles to integers. Nevertheless, it gives a proper intuition about the refinement steps.
1. Represent all points with respect to the observer location (perform a translation) 
2. Transform all points to polar coordinates such that they are represented by distance(not needed for this problem) and an integer angle with respect to the observer.
3. Create a count vector of size $360+FOV$, with index that represents the angle and value the frequency (e.g. number of points) represented by that angle (ignore points exactly at observer location). Note that the array considers also FOV bonus locations in order to evaluate all possible windows that are placed in an interval that crosses angle 360 and 0 (which represent the same angular location).
4. Given the obtained counts, transform such array to a prefix sum array.
5. Compute number of points within window of size $FOV$ starting at 
  $x \in [0,360]$ by means of the prefix sum computedbefore $cur\_count = prefix\_sum[x+FOV]-prefix\_sum[x-1] $
6. Return $max_{i}(cur\_count_i) + K$, where K is the number of previously ignored points.

# Approach
Note: this will be an in depth explanation that covers deeply all concepts.
Just glance through it if you want to just see the code.
Furthermore, the general setting of this problem is that of an engineering problem more than a CS one.
So you might need a bit more math knowledge for this.

#### Three concepts are fundamental to fully understand this problem:
* **Calculus**: any point x,y in cartesian coordinates can be mapped to another set of coordinates u,v.
Since the field of view (FOV for short) is here represented by an angle, it would  be neat **to have points and FOV in the same unit of measurement e.g. angles**. **Polar coordinates** allow to map a point **x,y in cartesian coordinates (x,y) to polar(radius,angle)**.
This is achieved as follows:
. $$radius = (x^2+y^2)^{\frac{1}{2}}$$
. $$angle=arctan(y/x)$$

Read here for more details https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_coordinate_system#Converting_between_polar_and_Cartesian_coordinates ). Here radius is not relevant since the problem states that you can "see" behind points on the same line of sight, otherwise you would need it.  


* **Sliding window**: Now that the field of view and the points are represent both as angles, we can
conceptualize the field of view as a window/interval/range which has size equal to the provided field of view angle ). Hence the problem is reduced to finding the sliding window that contains the maximum number of points. 
Still, where should we slide the window that represents the field of view?
It should be slid by placing it at any of the points x,y represented by their angle $\theta$, and considering the FOV area after it: this is represented by the interval $[\theta, \theta + FOV]$, in which $FOV$ is basically the sliding window size.

* **Coordinate translation**: 
points have to be represented with respect to the observer location, since the field of view has to be considered based on that position. 
Up to now, the location of the observer (given in the problem as "location")
has not been taken into account when considering angles and sliding windows. Indeed the data is given to us with respect to the origin of the plane. 
However, as stated in the problem, we need to determine all quantities with respect to the observer's field of view.
This can be solved by simply translating all points such that they are represented with respect to the observer location, rather than the origin of the axis.
As an example, if the observer is located at location=$(x_{obs}=1,y_{obs}=1)$ (with respect to the origin $(0,0)$), a point $(x=1,y=0)$ (also with respect to the origin), 
the observer would see it exactly below its location, thus at 
$(x_{new}=0,y_{new}=-1)$. Therefore to achieve this result, every point has to be represented relative to the observer location.
This is mathematically achieved by a simple translation:
. $$x_{new}=x-x_{obs}$$
. $$y_{new}=y-y_{obs}$$

* **Edge cases**
  All points that after the translations are exactly below the observer are deemed at angle 0 (because $arctan(0)=0$) with respect to it. Still, any points located exactly at the observer location has to be considered as visible by any field of view sliding window. Thus, these are excluded and added back to the result after all computations are performed.

# Complexity
N = number of points
- Time complexity:
$$O(N \log N)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(N)$$
# Code
```


class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        t = Solution.t
        to_angle = Solution.to_angle            
        
        points_at_location = 0
        angles = []
        for point in points:
            x1,y1 = t(*point, *location)
            if x1 == 0 and y1 == 0:
                points_at_location += 1
                continue
            ang = to_angle(x1,y1) 
            angles.append(ang)

            if ang >= 0 and ang < angle:
                angles.append(ang+360)
        angles = sorted(angles)
        max_s = 0
        j = 0
        for i in range(0, len(angles)):
            
            while angles[i]-angles[j] > angle:
                j += 1

            max_s = max(i-j+1, max_s)
        return max_s + points_at_location


    def t(x,y, x0,y0):
        x1 = x-x0
        y1 = y-y0
        return x1,y1
    
    def to_angle(x,y):
        angle = (math.atan2(y,x)/(math.pi))*180 
        if angle < 0:
            angle += 360
        return angle
```

```
def visiblePoints(self, ps: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
	a, b = location[0], location[1]
	n = sum([1 for x, y in ps if x==a and y==b])

	ps_angle = sorted([atan2(y-b, x-a) for x, y in ps if x!=a or y!=b])
	ps_angle += [(k + 2.0*pi) for k in ps_angle]

	angle = radians(angle)
	
	# Two-points method to find Longest Contiguous Subarray
	# such that the angle difference of tail and head < angle
	
	ans, hi = 0, 0
	for lo in range(len(ps_angle)):
		while(hi<len(ps_angle) and ps_angle[lo]+angle>=ps_angle[hi]):
			hi += 1
		ans = max(ans, hi-lo)
	return ans+n
```

solutions.content:
# Idea
We first find the angles of all points, then we sort all the angles and do a sliding window over them. The points whose angle is `<= angle` are added twice, to simulate the circling behavior.
```
def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        a, b = location
        to_360 = lambda angl: 180 + angl * 180 / pi
        onpoint = 0
        maxvisible = 0
        degrees = []
        for x, y in points:
            if [x, y] == location: 
                onpoint += 1
                continue
            deg = to_360(atan2(y - b, x - a))
            degrees.append(deg)
            if deg <= angle:
                degrees.append(deg + 360)
        
        degrees.sort()
        left = 0
        for right in range(len(degrees)):
            while degrees[right] - degrees[left] > angle:
                left += 1
            maxvisible = max(maxvisible, right - left + 1)
            
        return maxvisible + onpoint
```

```
import math
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int: 
        angles = [ ]
        maxcount = 0
        always_visible = 0
        x1, y1 = location
        for x2, y2 in points:
            # we always need to include this point, irrespective of the angle
            if x1== x2 and y2 == y1:
                always_visible +=1
            else:
                ang_rad = math.atan2((y2-y1),(x2-x1))  
                angles.append(math.degrees(ang_rad))
                # create a continuously increasing sequence by
                #converting -ve angles to +ve by adding 360
                if angles[-1] < 0:
                    angles.append(angles[-1] + 360)
        angles.sort()
        left, right = 0,0
        #sliding window
        while right < len(angles):
            while (angles[right] - angles[left]) > angle:
                left += 1
                #print ("L",left,right)
            maxcount  = max (maxcount, right -left +1)
            right +=1
        return maxcount + always_visible
```

```
class Solution(object):
    def visiblePoints(self, points, angle, location):
        """
        :type points: List[List[int]]
        :type angle: int
        :type location: List[int]
        :rtype: int
        """
        x0,y0 = location
		# to radians
        angle *= pi/180
        # transform points to location + filter + transform to polar angle
        angles = sorted([atan2(x-x0,y-y0) for x,y in points if x!=x0 or y!=y0])
        n = len(angles)
        angles += [2*pi+a for a in angles]
        l,r = 0,0
        maxview=0
        while l<n:
            while r<2*n and angles[r]-angles[l]<=angle:
                r+=1
            maxview = max(maxview,r-l)
            while l<n and angles[r]-angles[l]>angle:            
                l+=1
        return maxview + len(points)-n
```

```
import numpy as np
import bisect

def get_ang(x, y):
    innerp = x
    length = np.sqrt(x**2 + y**2)
    ang = np.arccos(innerp/length)
    if y < 0:
        ang = 2*np.pi - ang
    return 180 * ang / np.pi

class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        if angle >= 360:
            return len(points)
        cx, cy = location
        
        rst = 0
        ags = []
        for x, y in points:
            dx, dy = x-cx, y-cy
            if dx == 0 and dy == 0:
                rst += 1
                continue
            ang = get_ang(dx, dy)
            ags.append(ang)
            ags.append(ang+360)
        
        #print(ags)
        ags.sort()
        #print(ags)
        epsl = 1e-9
        to_add = 0
        for i, v in enumerate(ags):
            tgt = v + angle + epsl
            to_add = max(to_add, bisect.bisect_right(ags, tgt) - i)
        
        return rst + to_add
```

```
import numpy as np
import bisect

def get_ang(x, y):
    innerp = x
    length = np.sqrt(x**2 + y**2)
    ang = np.arccos(innerp/length)
    if y < 0:
        ang = 2*np.pi - ang
    return 180 * ang / np.pi

class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        if angle >= 360:
            return len(points)
        cx, cy = location
        
        rst = 0
        ags = []
        for x, y in points:
            dx, dy = x-cx, y-cy
            if dx == 0 and dy == 0:
                rst += 1
                continue
            ang = get_ang(dx, dy)
            ags.append(ang)
            ags.append(ang+360)
        
        #print(ags)
        ags.sort()
        #print(ags)
        epsl = 1e-9
        to_add = 0
        for i, v in enumerate(ags):
            tgt = v + angle + epsl
            to_add = max(to_add, bisect.bisect_right(ags, tgt) - i)
        
        return rst + to_add
```

solutions.title: kotlin-functional-programming
solutions.content:
# Steps:
**Step 1: Map Points to Angles**	 (this part we do with functional programming)
* center points to origin
* filter out points on center/where you stand
* use atan2 to get full 360 degres not just 180
* sort
* append same array with +360 for each element

**Step 2: Use sliding window to go over array**
* whenever your window is too large for your view, increase left pointer
* otherwise increase right pointer (make window larger)
* count points you see and compare against opt found

**Step 3: Return result**
* return with `+points.size - a.size / 2` to account for the filtered out origin points

**Total Complexity**
Runtime: `O(n*lg2(n))` due to sorting
Space: `O(n)`

**Code**
```
fun visiblePoints(points: List<List<Int>>, angle: Int, loc: List<Int>): Int {
    val a = points.map { listOf(it[0] - loc[0], it[1] - loc[1]) } // center
        .filter { it[0] != 0 || it[1] != 0 } // filter same loc/standpoint points
        .map { Math.atan2(it[1].toDouble(), it[0].toDouble()) } // map to angles
        .sorted() // sort
        .let { it + it.map { it + Math.PI*2 } } // expand
    var l = 0
    var r = 0
    var vis = 0
    while (r <= a.lastIndex) {
        if (a[r] - a[l] <= angle.toDouble()/180*Math.PI) {
            vis = maxOf(vis, r - l + 1)
            r++
        } else l++
    }
    return vis + points.size - a.size / 2
}
```

```
from math import atan2
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], viewangle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        lx, ly = location
        def anglefromme(x, y): return 180/math.pi * atan2(y-ly,x-lx)
        
        same_aslocation = sum(x==lx and y==ly for x,y in points)
        angles = sorted(anglefromme(x,y) for x, y in points if (x,y) != (lx, ly) ) # just need angles
        angles += [x + 360 for x in angles if x < 0]  # because points below x axis (Q3, Q4) also can be after the points in Q2
         
        ans = left = 0
        for idx, angle in enumerate(angles): 
            while angle - angles[left] > viewangle:
                left += 1
            # else:
            ans = max(ans, idx - left + 1)
                
        return ans+same_aslocation
```

python-binary-search-o-n-log-n-gotchas
solutions.content:
# Algorithm
1. Converthe Cartesian coordinates to points (`phi`) on the [unit circle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_circle).
2. Sort the points to facilate binary search
3. Apply binary search over a sliding window

# Complexity
`O(n log n)`.
Converting to Cartesian coordinates is `O(n)`. (`math.atan2()` is slow, so this is the longest step in practice.)

Sorting is `O(n log n)`

We invoke binary search at most `2n` times, so the final step is `O(n log n)`.

# Gotchas
## Wrapping the binary search.
The binary search needs to handle intervals that include the singularity `phi = 0`. The standard trick is to break the interval into two intervals on each side of the singularity.

## Points at origin
Note that `math.atan2(x,y)` is undefined when `x = 0` and `y = 0`. We need to count such points seperately.

# Code

```python
import bisect
class Solution:
    # Counts points between r1 and r2 clockwise.
    # Eg assume r1 <= r2 unless range includes phi = 0
    def countVisiblePoints(self, r1: float, r2: float) -> int:
        # Normalize any overflow.
        r1 = r1 % 1
        r2 = r2 % 1
        # Count points, but assume phi = 0 is NOT included in span.
        def countHelper(r1: float, r2: float) ->int:
            leftIndex = bisect.bisect_left(self.phiVals, r1)
            rightIndex = bisect.bisect_right(self.phiVals, r2)
            return rightIndex - leftIndex
        if r1 > r2:
            return countHelper(r1, 1) + countHelper(0, r2)
        else:
            return countHelper(r1, r2)
        
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        # Convert to the unit circle.
        angle = angle / 360.0
        
        # Step 1:Adjust points so viewpoint is at origin.
        for point in points:
            point[0] -= location[0]
            point[1] -= location[1]
        # Points at orgin are always visible.
        self.phiZeroCount = 0
        
        # Convert to polar coordinates and normalize phi to a point on the unit circle.
        # By abuse of notation, we still use phi to refer to the resulting value.
        self.phiVals = []
        pointsAtOrigin = 0
        for point in points:
            if point[0] == 0 and point[1] == 0:
                pointsAtOrigin += 1
                continue
            phi = (math.pi + math.atan2(point[1],point[0])) / (2*math.pi)
            self.phiVals += [ phi ]
			
        # Step 2: Sort to facilitate binary search.
        self.phiVals.sort()

		# Step 3:
        maxVis = 0
        for phi in self.phiVals:
            # Case 1: Consider slices [phi,phi + angle]
            visiblePoints = self.countVisiblePoints(phi, phi + angle)
            maxVis = max(maxVis,visiblePoints)
            
        return maxVis + pointsAtOrigin
```

python-sliding-window-and-sort
solutions.content:
The key is to deal with periodic property of angles. Append the sorted angle array to its self, but offset by 360 will do the trick.
Notice there is an edge case, if a point overlaps with the observer, it is always visible.

```
class Solution:
    import math
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        n = len(points)
        pi = 4.0*math.atan(1.0)
        points1 = []
        
        n_over = 0
        for i in range(n):
            dx = points[i][0]-location[0]
            dy = points[i][1]-location[1]
            
            if(dx==0 and dy==0): 
                n_over += 1
                continue
            
            r = (dx*dx+dy*dy)**0.5
            phi = math.acos(dx/r)*180/pi
            if(dy<0):
                phi *= -1
            #print(dx, dy, phi)
            points1.append(phi)
        points1 = sorted(points1)
        points1 = points1 + [x+360 for x in points1]
        
        
        ## sliding window
        i = 0; j = 0
        ans = 0
        n1 = len(points1)
        #print(points1, n1)
        while(i<n1 and j<n1):
            while(j<n1 and points1[j]-points1[i]<angle+1e-8):
                ans = max(ans, j-i+1)
                j+=1
            #print(i, j)
            if(j==n1): break
            if(i<j): i += 1
        return ans+n_over
    ```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        angles = []
        count = 0
        
        for point in points:
            # center point coordinates at location
            x = point[0] - location[0]
            y = point[1] - location[1]
            # pre-count the number of points at the start location and keep as
            # an offset to add to the final result; do not calculate angles
            # for these offset points
            if x == 0 and y == 0:
                count += 1
                continue
            # get the angle for each point (which can be viewed as a vector from origin and its angle with the X axis) in degrees; the range of atan2 is (-pi, pi).
            ang = math.degrees(math.atan2(y, x))
            angles.append(ang)
            # The trick is that the list of angles must be viewed as circular and
            # the easiest way to circle back the angles is to add the 360 offset
            angles.append(ang + 360)
        
        angles.sort()
        
        # standard two-pointer pattern to process all points' angles that can
        # be seen in the same view and take the view with the highest num of points
        # which is equivalent with the longest stretch within the angle span
        start, end, maxn = 0, 0, 0
        while end < len(angles) - 1:
            end += 1
            if start < end and angles[end] - angles[start] > angle:
                start += 1
            maxn = max(maxn, end - start + 1)
    
        return maxn + count
```

solutions.content:
Tricks:
* Shift the coordinate to `location`.
* Remove points that located at origin after the shift
* Use numpy `angle` instead of `arctan` and specify `deg=True` to get the degree directly
* Periodicity is handled by extending the angles list by the same array + 360
* Sliding window count takes O(N)
```
import numpy as np

class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        x0, y0 = location
		# since the points at the origin won't be handled properly, we count them seperately
        n_zeros = 0
        for x, y in points:
            if x == x0 and y == y0:
                n_zeros += 1
		# turn coordinates into complex numbers for np.angle
        compl = [(x - x0) + (y - y0)*1j for x, y in points if not (x == x0 and y == y0)]
        angles = np.angle(compl, deg=True)  # output -180 to 180
        angles = np.sort(angles)
        angles = list(angles) + list(angles + 360)  # so that we can handle the periodicity
		# Sliding window count (Time complexity O(N))
        max_count = 0
        j = 0  # index for left point
        for i, r in enumerate(angles):
            l = angles[j]
			# move the left by 1 if r - l not within the angle
            while r - l > angle:
                j += 1
                l = angles[j]
            max_count = max(max_count, i - j + 1)
        return max_count + n_zeros
```

```
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        x0, y0 = location
```
```
        ans = ovlp = 0
        theta = [] 
        for x, y in points: 
            if x == x0 and y == y0: ovlp += 1
            else: theta.append(atan2(y-y0, x-x0)) # (x, y) wrt (x0, y0)
        
        theta.sort()
        theta += [x+2*pi for x in theta]
        ii = 0
        for i in range(len(theta)): 
            while theta[i] - theta[ii] > angle*pi/180: ii += 1
            ans = max(ans, i-ii+1)
        return ans + ovlp
```

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        vectors = [(p1-location[0],p2-location[1]) for p1,p2 in points]
        pi = 3.141592653589793238462643383279502884197
        def myatan(a1,a2):
            if a1 > 0:
                return atan(a2/a1) / pi*180
            elif a1<0:
                return atan(a2/a1) / pi*180 + 180
            else:
                return 90 if a2>0 else -90
        myvectors = [v for v in vectors if v!=(0,0)]
        angles = sorted([myatan(a1,a2) for a1,a2 in myvectors])
        
        i,j = 0,0
        n = len(angles)
        less = len(vectors) - n
        res = 0
        angles += [x+360 for x in angles] // this line is crucial for sliding windows to work on a circle
        n = len(angles)
        while j<n:
            while angles[j]-angles[i] > angle:
                i += 1
            j += 1
            res = max(res,j-i)
        return res+less
            
        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
In order to solve this, one needs to figure out how to compute the angles of points to our current position.

Once you have this array of angles, you can sort it and just do a typical sliding window maximization.

The tangens of the angle from us to our points is the distance in y divided by the distance in x. As we need to calculate the angle, we need to use the inverted tanges: arcus tangens. Normally the arcus tangens is only defined from (-90, 90)\xB0, but in python we can use the atan2 function, which takes the y and x separately and already returns the angle in the right quadrant (-180, 180)\xB0.

Other than that one needs to know, that the geometrical functions (tan, cos, sin) in most programming languages return the angle in radians (multiples of pi). One pi corresponds to 180\xB0.

Therefore we either convert the radians to angles (* 180/pi) or the field of view to radians (* pi/189).

After that we can do a sliding window maximization with the constraint of the difference of the minimum and the maximum angle beeing equal or smaller than our field of view.

One needs to keep in mind, that the angles are mod360 circular, so we need to extend our sliding window over the end of the real array until the left pointer (smaller angles) hits the end. angles where the pointer has left the end of the array and goes back in the front need to be increassed by 360.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Geometrical functions and sliding window over circular array.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(N*logN) for the sorting
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(N) for the angles
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], fov: int, location: List[int]) -> int:

        # compute the angle of all points to myself
        angles = []
        equal = 0
        rad2angle = 180/math.pi
        for point in points:

            # check whether the point is the same as we are
            if point == location:
                equal += 1
                continue
            
            # get the arcus tangens for the angle with the correct quadrant information
            angles.append(math.atan2(point[1] - location[1], point[0] - location[0])*rad2angle)
        
        # sort the angles
        angles.sort()

        # compute a sliding window, while doing that we need to keep in mind that the angles
        # are mod360 degree circular, so we need to extend our range check over the end of the
        # array
        result = 0
        left = 0
        right = 0
        while left < len(angles):

            # get the current angle
            angle = angles[right] if right < len(angles) else angles[right % len(angles)] + 360
            
            # update the sliding window
            left_angle = angles[left] if left < len(angles) else angles[left % len(angles)] + 360
            while angle - left_angle > fov:
                left += 1
                left_angle = angles[left] if left < len(angles) else angles[left % len(angles)] + 360
            
            # update the result
            result = max(result, right-left+1)

            # update the right pointer
            right += 1
        return result + equal
            
```

solutions.title: js-sliding-window-technique-with-o-n-log-n
solutions.content:
# Approach
 Sliding window technique.
- The code first initializes an array called `arr` to store the angles between each point and the given location.
- The code calculates the angle between each point and the given location using the `Math.atan2` function.
- If the point has the same location as the given location, it increments the extra variable.
- The code then sorts the `arr` in ascending order.
- The `arr` is then concatenated with itself with each angle increased by `2 * pi`.
- The given angle is converted from degrees to radians.
- The code then uses two pointers `l` and `r`, to find the maximum number of points in the `arr` that have an angle difference less than or equal to the given angle.
- If the angle difference between `arr[r]` and `arr[l]` is greater than the given angle,`l` is incremented.
- The `ans` variable stores the maximum number of points with an angle difference less than or equal to the given angle.
- The final result is the sum of `ans` and extra.

# Complexity
Time Complexity: O(n log n) where n is the number of points. The sorting of the arr takes O(n log n) time and the two-pointer approach takes O(n) time.

Space Complexity: O(n). The code uses an array of size n to store the angles between each point and the given location.

# Code
```
/**
 * @param {number[][]} points
 * @param {number} angle
 * @param {number[]} location
 * @return {number}
 */
var visiblePoints = function(points, angle, location) {
    let arr = [], extra = 0
    let [xx, yy] = location
    
    for (let [x, y] of points) {
        if (x == xx && y == yy) {
            extra += 1
            continue
        }
        arr.push(Math.atan2(y - yy, x - xx))
    }
    
    arr.sort((a, b) => a - b)
    arr = arr.concat(arr.map(x => x + 2.0 * Math.PI))
    angle = Math.PI * angle / 180
    
    let l = ans = 0
    for (let r = 0; r < arr.length; r++) {
        while (arr[r] - arr[l] > angle) {
            l += 1
        }
        ans = Math.max(ans, r - l + 1)
    }
    
    return ans + extra
}
```

solutions.title: angles-are-converted-to-rad-and-then-modified-binary-search-applied-to-find-the-points
solutions.content:
# Intuition
First the tanget wrt the location is calculated. All the points that have the same coordinates as the location is removed from the list. They are common points to all the possible angle spread.
The angles are obtained from the tangent in [-pi, pi] range. They are converted into [0, 2pi] range. 
The list of angles is sorted in ascending order 
for each angle in the list, a window of possible points is generated based on the angle provided in the problem. 
If the angle spread is within 2pi range, then modified binary search is applied on the whole range to find max points.
Else all the points till the end of the list are added and the binary search is applied on the starting of the list till the iterated angle. The logic here is that points closer to the x axis can have some points in the starting of the list due to circular nature of angles.


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(nlog n)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```
# import numpy as np
from math import atan2, pi, floor
class Solution:
    def binary_search(self, arr, start_index, end_index, value):
        if start_index < 0:
            return -1
        if start_index <= end_index:
            mid = floor((start_index + end_index)/2)
            # print(start_index, end_index, mid)
            if arr[mid] <= value:
                search_index = self.binary_search(arr, mid + 1, end_index, value)
                if search_index != -1:
                    return search_index
                else:
                    return mid
            else:
                return self.binary_search(arr, start_index, mid - 1, value)
        else:
            return -1
    def get_angle(self, point, location):
        angle_in_rad = atan2((point[1] - location[1]),(point[0] - location[0]))
        if angle_in_rad < 0:
            return 2*pi + angle_in_rad
        else:
            return angle_in_rad
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        angles = [self.get_angle(point, location) for point in points if not (point[0] == location[0] and point[1] == location[1])]
        angle_in_rad = pi * angle/180
        points_at_base = 0
        for point in points:
            if point[0] == location[0] and point[1] == location[1]:
                points_at_base += 1
        _angles = sorted(angles)
        # print(_angles)
        max_points = 0
        for i in range(len(_angles)):
            curr_max_points = 0
            if _angles[i] + angle_in_rad <= 2*pi:
                index = self.binary_search(_angles, i + 1, len(_angles) - 1, _angles[i] + angle_in_rad)
                curr_max_points += 1
                if index != -1:
                    curr_max_points += index - i
                # for j in range(i, len(_angles)):
                #     if _angles[j] - _angles[i] <= angle_in_rad:
                #         curr_max_points += 1
                #     else:
                #         break
            else:
                curr_max_points = len(_angles) - i
                index = self.binary_search(_angles, 0, i - 1, _angles[i] + angle_in_rad - 2*pi)
                if index != -1:
                    curr_max_points += index + 1
                # for j in range(0, i):
                #     if _angles[j] <= _angles[i] + angle_in_rad - 2*pi:
                #         curr_max_points += 1
                #     else:
                #         break
            if curr_max_points > max_points:
                        max_points = curr_max_points
            
        return max_points + points_at_base




```

sort-and-sweep-two-pointers
solutions.content:
# Intuition
Sort all points by their angle to you and +x, counter-clockwise. Then it's quick to look around, counting points that come into view and subtracting those that go out of view.

# Approach
Keep two indices i and j, move j forwards until just before the FOV ($$angle$$) to see both i and j breaches the threshold. The points i to j, inclusive, are a possible maximum to return. Increment i and repeat for all points.

The remaining complexity is to be able to wrap j so that you can start including/"seeing" points back at the start towards the end of your full turn.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n \log{n})$$, due to sorting

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$

# Code
```
import math

class Solution:
    def visiblePoints(self, points: List[List[int]], angle: int, location: List[int]) -> int:
        # degrees are bad for maths
        fov = math.radians(angle)

        # Make the points relative to the viewer
        relpoints = list((p[0]- location[0], p[1]- location[1]) for p in points)

        # count the number of points we're standing on, to be added at the end
        standing_on = relpoints.count((0, 0))

        # make a list of sorted angles to every point that we're not standing on
        # uses atan2(), which automatically figures out which quadrant the angle is in and gives a full 0 to 2 pi range
        angles = sorted(math.atan2(p[0], p[1]) for p in relpoints if p != (0, 0))

        # returns angles[i], accounting for wrapping back to the start and adding 2 pi each time it does
        wrap_angle = lambda i: angles[i % len(angles)] + (i // len(angles)) * math.pi * 2.0

        # Sweep a view in a full circle (all points) between angles[i] and angles[j] such that it's never bigger than fov
        j = 0
        result = 0
        for i, start in enumerate(angles):
            # increase j until incrementing one more time would breach the fov angle
            while j + 1 - i < len(angles) and wrap_angle(j + 1) - start <= fov:
                j += 1

                # debugging
                #print(i, math.degrees(start), j, math.degrees(angles[j % len(angles)]))
            
            # Placing point i on the right, the max points we can currently see is from i to j inclusive
            result = max(result, j - i + 1)

            #print(i, j)

        return result + standing_on

```

```
        # degrees are bad for maths

        # uses atan2(), which automatically figures out which quadrant the angle is in and gives a full 0 to 2 pi range
        angles = sorted(math.atan2(p[0], p[1]) for p in relpoints if p != (0, 0))

        # returns angles[i], accounting for wrapping back to the start and adding 2 pi each time it does
        wrap_angle = lambda i: angles[i % len(angles)] + (i // len(angles)) * math.pi * 2.0
```
